content.description: Excellent problem! Many moves on schist and granite. Tall but a perfectly flat landing. Sit start towards the center of the wall on the left to right angling rail. Crux is in the first few moves. Continue on cool crimps through the diagonal schist band and make a large span out left to a sloper dish. Make rad moves to reach the large sloper shelf above, then traverse further left to top out the same as for "Swamp Surfer".A V7 stand start can be done from the two small, side by side slopers, just a few moves in.
content.location: Left-center of the wall. Route trends up and left.

content.description: Stand start on flat ledge. Easy movement up the trough leads up and right to a tricky exit out the bulge. Top out as for "Take to Whiskey". Throw your pads down on the log-filled swamp and hang ten!

An easier, alternate start to 'Steelman'. SDS on jugs, work through a band of large crystals then head left into the schist jugs. Drop off the large protruding shelf. May want to downclimb a few moves even...kinda far to drop.
content.location: Rightmost problem on the wall. Sit start is tucked in the back of the gully next to other rocks.

content.description: The left and the harder of these two lines. Good warm-up for the other problems on the wall. Stand start on good edges and follow the schist blobs up and right into the sculpted jugs. Then straight up to the shelf. A top out up and right is doable but dropping off is recommended.
content.location: Far right side of the wall, around the corner.

climbs.name: Passing The Guard
climbs.fa: Dan Dewell  2nd Ascent: Jason Mcnabb  3rd Ascent: probably when its not a swamp due to global warming...

content.description: SDS on decent holds. Work up and slightly out towards the arête on crimps and indents. The top of the problem transfers onto the face in the water grooves.  Look for Tree right by arête. Do You Have What It Takes?
content.protection: A few pads will ease the mind
content.location: This is the wall facing south in the swamp area by The Love Knob formation. If you were walking beneath the Love Knob routes heading North you would run right into this wall. Can't miss it.

content.description: PTG stands for Passing The Guard which is the namesake problem on the corner. This wall has room for a few more problems. The "Projects" to the left of PTG are tall and complex. This wall is slightly overhanging. With a little cleaning these problems could be some of the hardest in the area. Dan Dewell and Blake Workman both cleaned and worked these but had no luck. In the wetter months a nice pool forms at the base. This can either benefit or make it unclimbable. Summer will be dry for most of the time. Stays shaded. With the Pool usually at the base during Spring it can create a SWAMPY mess to try and get to this wall. Along with all the fallen trees this problem likely won't see any traffic until the area cleans up. Awesome stone in a not so awesome area.
